captions.text: A laptop for Gokul in Chennai
Roller skates for Pinky in Delhi
And a watch for Hiral in Mumbai
Today, online shopping has made life so easy for us in India
Everything is delivered at our doorstep
But have we ever wondered
about those who bring them to us?
[Man talking on phone]
When I go to make a delivery
The customer becomes happy seeing his parcel
His happiness makes us happy
Pinky! Your roller skates!
Thank you Mom!
One time, I'd gone to make a delivery
Some kids were playing nearby
They saw my big bag and started shrieking
"Jingle bells! Jingle bells!"
Just seeing the bag!
Ma'am, I have a parcel for you
[on the phone] Oh yes! But I'm not at home right now!
Ma'am, you'd asked me to come at this time
[on the phone] Really sorry, can you come back at 4 o'clock please?
Each day, thousands of people
ride across the length and breadth of this country
to make this possible
Without even a little thank-you in return
During GOSF, India's most popular online shopping festival
Google decided to do something special
for these nameless heroes
Is this Mr. Hanumant's house?
Are you Mr. Hanumant?
I have a delivery for you!
Thank you, sir!

title: #SpecialDelivery: Celebrating the unsung heroes of online shopping

comments.author: Lee Xiu Mei

comments.text:
In our world of big names, curiously, our true heroes tend to be anonymous. 
In this life of illusion and quasi-illusion, the person of solid virtues 
who can be admired for something more substantial than his well-knownness 
often proves to be the unsung hero: the teacher, the nurse, the mother, the 
honest cop, the hard worker at lonely, underpaid, unglamorous, unpublicized 
jobs.﻿

comments.author: Ambar Das

comments.text:
Did we ever think of doing it to our old post masters who even today 
deliver our letters/couriers via cycle? What is a big deal I do not 
understand. Somebody does something and we do not either praising or 
kindling them. Stop sharing such things or even commenting for that matter. 
These guys get paid for what they do and i personally checked with many, 
they also get petrol allowances as well. Please note that this is my 
personal opinion and nothing to criticize what people are doing. Just think 
twice before liking or sharing something of this sot. With online shopping, 
we have twken away bread and butter of many shop keepers, watchmans, 
Sweepers etc who were associated with these shops. Thank you for reading 
thru my comment.﻿
comments.author: shiningsunil

comments.text:

comments.text: Say Thank You! ﻿
comments.author: Amith Raravi

comments.text:
Seriously guys you needed Google to tell you that its good to thank other 
people when they do something for you regardless if they are being paid or 
not ? Apparently people were never taught the 4 magic words in India. Our 
society has a long way to go, we still have "educated grown ups" learning 
how to say thank you. The problem lies in the foundation our education 
system which focuses more just mugging up words which children then "throw 
up" on the answer sheet. Rather than developing responsible, well mannered 
and competent people who can contribute to our society. ﻿

comments.author: olalekan adeboyejo

comments.text:
I appreciate the initiative taken by Google, heartily. But, this is not 
enough,life of such people (unorganised poorly financed worker) can not 
depend, only on discrete initiatives. The government has to come forward 
with laws of minimum wage scales, minimum tenure of service and health 
benefit of the workers. All the business companies have to have this thing 
in mind, that those rules are strictly to be followed to get the 'renewable 
clearance' to doing business and hence that so-called 'clearance' can be 
adjourned otherwise. This is mandatory, for any developed country! Unless 
and until India looses its tag like 'land of cheap laborers', it can not do 
well in economy..﻿
